newsitem.title: USA: U.S. House panel approves Eximbank renewal.
newsitem.headline: U.S. House panel approves Eximbank renewal.

text.p: A House panel voted Thursday to extend the U.S. Export-Import Bank for four years after making three modest changes in its charter.
The independent federal agency helps exports by providing loans and guarantees for the purchase of American products but critics have charged that its mission is one of "corporate welfare."

Republican Rep Michael Castle of Delaware, chairman of a House Banking subcommittee, supported the reauthorization, saying that part of the bank's purpose was to "neutralize aggressive financing by foreign export credit agencies."
The reauthorization bill, which now goes to the full Banking Committee, establishes an advisory committee to recommend ways to help boost exports to sub-Saharan Africa.

It also clarifies procedures under which the president may prevent the bank from taking final action on a loan based on foreign policy interests and creates the position of a general counsel to handle administrative law and ethical matters.
The subcommittee defeated a series of amendments by Independent Rep Bernie Sanders of Vermont setting conditions on Eximbank loans to "change the rules regarding corporate welfare."
